1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Primary IGF-1 deficiency (Severe): initial, 0.5 mg/kg SUBQ once daily
  • Primary IGF-1 deficiency (Severe): maintenance, 1 to 2 mg/kg SUBQ once daily; MAX 2 mg/kg daily; reduce dose if adverse events occur including hypoglycemia and/or IGF-1 levels that are greater than or equal to 3 standard deviation above the normal reference range for insulin-like growth factor-1

2.title: Dose Adjustments
2.mono:
• undetectable acid-labile subunit (ALS) levels at baseline may require higher mecasermin doses
  • reduce dose if adverse events occur including hypoglycemia
  • reduce dose if IGF-1 levels that are greater than or equal to 3 standard deviation above the normal reference range for insulin-like growth factor-1

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• allergy to mecasermin rinfabate or any component of the formulation
  • closed epiphyses; should not be used for growth promotion
  • intravenous administration
  • neoplasia, active or suspected; discontinue therapy if neoplasia subsequently develops

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• high-risk activities; limit activities until tolerability has been established due to hypoglycemic effect
  • hypoglycemic effect, especially in small children because of unpredictable oral intake; administer shortly before or after a meal or snack
  • intracranial hypertension with papilledema may occur
  • lymphoid tissue hypertrophy, tonsillar and adenoidal; may result in complications such as excessive snoring, sleep apnea, chronic middle ear effusions, hearing loss
  • scoliosis; progression due to rapid growth
  • sensitivity or allergic reactions may occur; discontinue treatment
  • should be used only by physicians experienced in the diagnosis and management of patients with grow disorders
  • slipped capital femoral epiphysis may occur with rapid growth

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Mecasermin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (5% or more)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Goiter (5% or more), Hyperglycemia (5% or more), Hypoglycemia (Mild) (31%)
  • Hematologic:Iron deficiency anemia (5% or more)
  • Hepatic:Elevated levels of transaminase & lactic acid dehydrogenase (Mild) (5% or more)
  • Immunologic:Antibody development (90%), Hypertrophy of adenoids (19%), Hypertrophy of tonsils (19%), Lymphadenopathy (5% or more)
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (5% or more), Bone pain (5% or more), Muscle atrophy (5% or more), Pain in limb (5% or more)
  • Neurologic:Headache (22%)
  • Ophthalmic:Optic disc edema (5% or more)
  • Renal:Hematuria (5% or more)
  • Reproductive:Cyst of ovary (5.5%)
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypoglycemia (Severe) (5.5%)
  • Neurologic:Raised intracranial pressure

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • for SUBQ use only; do not administer IV
  • patient should maintain a balanced diet; do not administer if the patient cannot or will not eat or if a meal is skipped
  • administer in the morning or evening at approximately the same time every day
  • withhold doses if signs or symptoms of hypoglycemia are present at the time of dosing
  • subsequent doses should not be increased to make up for a missed dose
  • injection site should be rotated to a different site with each injection; new injections should be given at least one inch from the previous injection site(s); do not inject into areas where the skin is tender, bruised, red, hard, or lipodystrophic
  • should be administered using sterile disposable syringes and needles via aseptic technique
  • thaw to room temperature by using hands to warm vial for approximately 2 minutes; do not administer until at room temperature; discard any unused portion
  • do not shake vial; swirl in a gentle rotary motion to ensure complete mixing

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• acromegaly
  • blood glucose at initiation and when a dose is increased.
  • fundoscopic examinations at initiation and periodically (detect papilledema-related intracranial hypertension)
  • height velocity; should increase at least 2 centimeters/year
  • insulin-like growth factor-1 levels 8 to 18 hours after the previous dose; target levels are 0 to +2 standard deviation score for age
  • lymphoid tissue examinations, periodically (detect hypertrophy)
  • progression of scoliosis with rapid growth
  • signs and symptoms of intracranial hypertension such as visual changes, headache, and nausea and/or vomiting
  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis with rapid growth.
  • undetectable acid-labile subunit (ALS) levels at baseline.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid high-risk activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized.
  • This drug may cause goiter, hypertrophy of tonsils/adenoids, lymphadenopathy, arthralgia, bone pain, pain in limbs, or hematuria.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (limp or pain, stiffness, limited movement of hip) or raised intracranial hypertension (visual changes, headache, nausea, vomiting).
  • Drug may cause hypo- or hyperglycemia. Instruct patients to monitor for and report severe or persistent hypoglycemia.
  • Patient should take drug within 20 min before or after a meal or snack. Advise patient to not take drug when a meal is skipped, as this may cause hypoglycemic effects.
  • Teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
  • Advise patient to rotate injection sites.
